title: MD
biography: Anthony Stephen Fauci (born 1940) is an American physician-scientist and immunologist who served as Director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID) for 38 years (1984–2022), making him the longest-serving head of a major NIH institute. Born in Brooklyn, New York, he graduated first in his class from Cornell University Medical College in 1966. Fauci is one of the world's most frequently cited scientists, with an h-index of 241 on Google Scholar. He has been a principal architect of U.S. policy responses to HIV/AIDS, SARS, Ebola, Zika, and COVID-19. His research on the pathogenesis of HIV and immunoregulatory mechanisms has been foundational to modern immunology. He received the Presidential Medal of Freedom in 2008.
